Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Analysis, Dynamics, Geometry, and Probability
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the workshop "Analysis, Dynamics, Geometry, and Probability" held at the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics (SCGP, located in Stony Brook, NY) on March 2-6, 2020. Although the central questions studied in these fields are different, they have had fruitful interaction, and each field has benefited from developments in the others. While some of these connections are centuries old, there have been exciting developments in recent years. The award will allow a diverse group of mostly early-career mathematicians to interact with more established researchers. Bringing together this group will provide an excellent opportunity for interaction, shared insight, and further development. The organizers expect this to be a valuable educational opportunity as well as a research conference. Holding this conference at the SCGP will make it accessible and visible to the physics community, leading to interactions that might not occur as readily otherwise.

The workshop will bring together experts from interconnected fields. One example is the connection between Brownian motion, harmonic measure, analysis of singular integrals, and geometric properties of domains. This topic relates how a randomly-moving particle sees the boundary of the region in which it moves, the equilibrium charge distribution on the boundary of this region, and classical questions in analysis. Another example concerns function theory and dynamical systems: which geometric properties of functions are most important in studying the associated dynamical system formed by the iterates of the function, and on the other hand, what can the dynamical system tell us about the geometry of the initial function? The speakers include prominent researchers from a wide range of areas, including computer science, applied mathematics, dynamical systems, probability, analysis, and geometry. Many speakers have a history of making good use of such interchanges for groundbreaking work, some with important practical applications. Some specific examples are Ingrid Daubechies’ work on wavelets and their numerous applications (for example, image compression), Peter Jones’ work on diffusion geometry for data analysis, Svitlana Mayboroda’s work on localization of waves (used in LED light design), and Assaf Naor’s work on metric embeddings and algorithms, with applications in computer science. For more details see http://scgp.stonybrook.edu/archives/29488

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Short

We held  a conference at the  Simon Center for Geometry and Physics (SCGP), which took place March 2--6, 2020.  The conference was organized by Hrant Hakobyan (Kansas State University), Kirill Lazebnik (California Institute of Technology) and Raanan Schul (SUNY Stony Brook). The scientific committee was Peter Jones, Misha Lyubich, Dennis Sullivan.

 

Website

http://scgp.stonybrook.edu/archives/29488

There, one can watch video recordings of the talks, see the schedule of talks as well as a list of posters that were presented.

A list of attendees is also available there.

 

 

A few details

We had a very intense schedule, of 24 long talks, 7 short talks (25 minutes) and 7 posters presented. Of these, 3 talks were by Stas Smirnov, a Fields medalist. Other notable speakers include Scott Sheffield, Xavier Tolsa, Tatiana Toro, Svitlana Mayboroda, Guy David, Assaf Naor. Nine of the talks were by recent Phd?s. Eight of the talks were given by women.

A major goal was to share ideas across different fields, and in this respect the conference was very successful. Almost all participants went to almost all talks despite the breadth of fields. Speakers made an effort to introduce new ideas in a digestible form and there were comments from the audience that helped even further. We will now provide several concrete examples.

The talk of Lasse Rempe-Gillen concerned constructing Riemann surfaces arising from equilateral triangulations, namely on a new result (joint with Chris BIshop) that all non-compact Riemann surfaces could be obtained by gluing equilateral triangles. At the end of the talk, Chris Bishop pointed out that random triangulations of compact surfaces are well studied in recent years in probability (in relation to quantum gravity), but that it is unclear whether there is a reasonable probability measure on the space of triangulations of a non-compact surface. This tied in to the talk of Russ Lyons. For instance, how likely is it that a random triangulation is close to equilateral?

Another instance of stimulating collaboration between fields was seen in Steffen Rohde's talk, in which a class of conformal objects ``true trees" which can be described probabilistically in terms of Brownian motion. A certain sequence of true trees were seen to conjecturally limit on a seemingly unrelated object: the limit set of a certain Schwarz reflection map. This Schwarz reflection map had been studied by several participating members of the conference, including Mikhail Lyubich and Sabyasachi Mukherjee, and Steffen's talk provided the opportunity for the two groups to discuss the connection.
